audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 8, Lesson 1. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Books for Unit 7 and Unit 8.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 7 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Vote for Lulu.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 9 spread>

audio.transcription: Review Phonics Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show phonics cards 19–44>

audio.transcription: Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show High-Frequency Word Cards 51–70>

audio.transcription: Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
Multimodal mini-lesson. Listen to the sounds.
<visual: ar articulation video>
This is the sound-spelling card for the r-controlled vowel /är/. The "a-r" spelling stands for the /är/ sounds. What sounds does the "a-r" spelling make in the word "barn?" <pause> "/är/."
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for r-Controlled Vowel /är/>

audio.transcription: Write the spelling several times. Say the /är/ sounds each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about the r-Controlled Vowel /är/, let’s blend some words with r-Controlled Vowel /är/ and other sounds to practice what we've learned. Listen as I sound out the first two words.
audio.notes: <visual: show blend words chart>

audio.transcription: /kaaat/, cat. /kääärrr/, car. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether’. Say the word nice and loud.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about levels of government. First, look at these four pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. city hall <pause>, flag <pause>, city council <pause>, speaker <pause>, audience. Look at the pictures of the city council and the speaker. What do you think they are talking about?
audio.notes: <visual: show vocabulary card>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about levels of government. The word is substantial. If something is substantial, it is large in size or amount.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, substantial>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and word, scale>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Serving the People at Every Level”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words substantial and scale>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about levels of government? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 1 in your Unit 8 Student Book. The title of this story is "Star Gardeners.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Star Gardeners. This story is about a class planting a garden for their community.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this story: options. Options are things to choose from. There are many options of fresh juices at the market. What are some food options you have for breakfast?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, options>

audio.transcription: Read the story. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: show story>

audio.transcription: Find the word that names what Carla wants to start.
audio.notes: <visual: show story>

audio.transcription: How does the class choose between the options of helping others in their community? Find the sentence that answers the question.
How does the garden help the community? Explain.
What do you think the neighbors will do at the party?
You can reread this story during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Write about what you would plant in a garden. <pause> Share your ideas with a partner before you write. Look back at the story for ideas.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

toc.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Substitute Initial and Final Sounds

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 8, Lesson 2. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 8.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 1 in your Unit 8 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Star Gardeners.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 1 spread>

slides.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Substitute Initial and Final Sounds

audio.transcription: Listen as I say a word: sat
audio.notes: <visual: show phonemic awareness image>

audio.transcription: Say the word sat, but change the beginning sound. Change /s/, to /m/. What's the new word? <pause> mat
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Now let's change the ending sound of a word. Listen as I say a word: sat
Say the word sat, but change the ending sound. Change /t/, to /d/. What's the new word? <pause> sad
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
This is the sound-spelling card for the r-controlled vowel /är/. The "a-r" spelling stands for the /är/ sounds. What sounds does the "a-r" spelling make in the word "barn?" <pause> "/är/."
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for r-Controlled Vowel /är/>

audio.transcription: Write the spelling several times. Say the /är/ sounds each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about the r-Controlled Vowel /är/, let’s blend some words with r-Controlled Vowel /är/ and other sounds to practice what we've learned. Listen as I sound out the first two words.
audio.notes: <visual: show blend words chart>

audio.transcription: /kaaat/, cat. /kääärrr/, car. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether’. Say the word nice and loud.
Let's learn some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: one, have, is, jump, my>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word one. Say the word with me. One. Which sounds do you hear in one? /w/ /u/ /n/. Blend the sounds together.
Spell the word with me: o-n-e. The word "one" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: have, is, jump, my.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about national parks. First, look at these three pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. glacier <pause>, Glacier Bay <pause>, geyser <pause>, trees <pause>, Yellowstone <pause>, The Grand Canyon <pause>, river <pause>, rock. Look at the pictures of Glacier Bay, Yellowstone, and The Grand Canyon. How are these places different from each other?
audio.notes: <visual: show vocabulary card>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about national parks. The word is sturdy. Something that is sturdy is strong and well made.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, sturdy>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, constant>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Visit America the Beautiful”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words sturdy and constant>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about national parks? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 2 in your Unit 8 Student Book. The title of this text is "Welcome to City Hall!” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Welcome to City Hall! This text describes the purpose of a city hall and how it’s an important place in a local community.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: participate. Participate means “to take part in." I want to participate in the school play. Which sports or after-school activities do you participate in?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, participate>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: show story>

audio.transcription: Find the name of a festival that might have posters hung up in a city hall.
audio.notes: <visual: show story>

audio.transcription: What is the history of city halls? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Summarize the different ways citizens can participate in events at their local, or nearby, city hall.
Not all places have city halls. Some have other kinds of buildings where decisions are made. Which government buildings are in your area?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: List three to five facts that you learned about city halls. <pause> Draw a picture to accompany your list.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

toc.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
toc.title: Blending Focus

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 8, Lesson 3. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 8.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 2 in your Unit 8 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Welcome to City Hall!” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 2 spread>

audio.transcription: Review Phonics Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show phonics cards 19–45>

audio.transcription: Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show High-Frequency Word Cards 51–75>

audio.transcription: Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
This is the sound-spelling card for the r-controlled vowel /är/. The "a-r" spelling stands for the /är/ sounds. What sounds does the "a-r" spelling make in the word "barn?" <pause> "/är/."
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for r-Controlled Vowel /är/>

audio.transcription: Write the spelling several times. Say the /är/ sounds each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about the r-Controlled Vowel /är/, let’s blend some words with r-Controlled Vowel /är/ and other sounds to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Let's find and circle all the words with art.
Now, let's put a box around all the words with ark.

slides.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
slides.title: Blending Focus

audio.transcription: Blending Focus: Use your letter cards to build each word I say. Let's start by doing one together. Make the word am. <pause> Add the letter r after a. What word did you make? Arm
audio.notes: <visual: show letters in e-pocket chart>

audio.transcription: Listen carefully as your teacher tells you the letter or letters to change to make the next word with your letter cards.

Let's build this set of words again. This time your teacher will not tell you which letters to change. Let's try one together: Make the word am <pause>. Now change am to arm. Which sound is different? Which letter will be different?

Build Words Booster: Let's do some more word building. Listen carefully as your teacher tells you which word to make with your letter cards. Your teacher will check your work. Think about each sound in the word you are making. Use letter cards to spell the word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the letter cards to build the words>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 3 in your Unit 8 Student Book. Today we are going to read some cumulative sentences. These sentences contain words with ar spellings and other phonics skills we have learned. Let’s whisper read one sentence at a time. When you are done, we will chorally read them together.
audio.notes: <visual: Show Cumulative Sentences, pages 12-13>

audio.transcription: Circle all the words with ar spellings. <pause> Turn to a partner and read the words. Your teacher will listen in.
Write a sentence using the word arm. <pause> When you are finished, read your sentence to a partner.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word arm>

audio.transcription: Write a sentence using each of these word pairs: far/park, artist/large.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word pairs far/park, artist/large>

toc.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus
Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 8, Lesson 4. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 8.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 3 in your Unit 8 Student Book. Whisper read the cumulative sentences.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 3 spread>

audio.transcription: Inflectional endings are suffixes. A suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the word's meaning.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word park and the phonics/syllable card "ed" across from it>

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "park." Add the inflectional ending "ed" to the end of "park." What is the new word?
parked. <pause> "parked" is the past-tense form of the verb "park." Adding the inflectional ending "ed" changes the tense of a verb from present tense to past tense.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word park and the phonics/syllable card "ed" across from it, under them, show the word "parked">

audio.transcription: Now add the inflectional ending "ing" to the end of the word "park." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word park and the phonics/syllable card "ing" across from it>

audio.transcription: parking. <pause> "Parking" is a present-tense verb that means the action "park" is happening now, such as in the sentence: Mr. Lang is parking his car. The inflectional ending "ing" is added to a verb to change the tense.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word park and the phonics/syllable card "ing" across from it, under them, show the word "parking">

audio.transcription: Practice adding inflectional endings "ed" and "ing" to the following words. Then create a sentence for each new word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the words start, jump, and help twice, once across from the phonics/syllable card ed and once across from the phonics/syllable card ing>

audio.transcription: This is the sound-spelling card for the r-controlled vowel /är/. The "a-r" spelling stands for the /är/ sounds. What sounds does the "a-r" spelling make in the word "barn?" <pause> "/är/."
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for r-Controlled Vowel /är/>

audio.transcription: Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Then, read each word as your teacher taps on it.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Select two words from the list. Write a sentence for each word.
Introduce High-Frequency Words. Let's learn some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: their, too, walk, where, year.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word their. Say the word with me. Their. The word "their" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Spell the word with me: t-h-e-i-r. The letters "ei" make the /âr/ sound in the word "their."
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: too, walk, where, year.

slides.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Listen to each word your teacher says. Write the word. If you need help, tap the sounds or use your sound boxes and counters to break up the word sound by sound. Then think about the letter that stands for each sound.
audio.notes: <visual: show phonemic awareness image>

audio.transcription: Let's start with these two words. Write the word far.
Now write the words hard and dark.

slides.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Spelling Booster: Let's write some more words. Listen to each word I say. Break apart the word sound by sound, then write the letter or spelling for each sound.
audio.notes: <visual: spelling booster image>

audio.transcription: arm
charm
star
start
match
march

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 4 in your Unit 8 Student Book. The title of this text is "Riddle Me This" Point to each word as you read the title with me: Riddle Me This. These are riddles. Each riddle contains clues that will help you identify the missing word. Read the riddles. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Find all the words in the riddles with ar spellings and circle them. <pause> Chorally read the circled words.
Write the sentence I say. Listen carefully and focus on one word at a time.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

audio.transcription: The first sentence is: Lucky never barks when we walk in the park. Say the sentence with me: Lucky never barks when we walk in the park. Now write the sentence. Your teacher will help you segment, or break apart, each word and write a letter for each sound.

The second sentence is: Can you discard that small carton of milk? Say the sentence with me: Can you discard that small carton of milk? Now write the sentence. Your teacher will help you if you need it.
Let's read each sentence out loud. Check your work. Your teacher will write each sentence. Correct your spellings if necessary.
Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 8, Lesson 5. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 8.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 4 in your Unit 8 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Riddle Me This.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 4 spread>

audio.transcription: Review Phonics Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show phonics cards 19–45>

audio.transcription: Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show High-Frequency Word Cards 61–80>

audio.transcription: Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.

Let's review inflectional endings "ed" and "ing." Inflectional endings are suffixes. A suffix is a word part that may be added to the end of a word. It can change the word’s meaning and part of speech.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "ed" and "ing">

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "bark." Add the inflectional ending "ed" to the end of "bark." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "bark" and the phonics/syllable card for "ed">

audio.transcription: "barked." <pause>"Barked" is the past-tense form of the verb "bark." The inflectional ending "ed" changes the tense of a verb from present-tense to past-tense.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "bark" and the phonics/syllable card for "ed", under them, show the word "barked">

audio.transcription: Now add the inflectional ending "ing" to the end of the word "bark." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word bark and the phonics/syllable card "ing" across from it>

audio.transcription: "barking." <pause> The inflectional ending "ing" often shows that an action is happening now, so "barking" means that the action, "bark," is happening now.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word bark and the phonics/syllable card "ing" across from it, under them, show the word "barking">

audio.transcription: Practice adding the inflectional endings "ed" and "ing" to the following words.
audio.notes: <visual: show each of the following words across from both endings "ed" and "ing": "march" "wait" "mix">

audio.transcription: Look at these words. Let's read the words together: mark, part , bark, start, shark, artist, chart, dark, smart, park. Now look at these two categories. This is the word artist. Read the word with me. <pause> Which category should I put artist under? <pause> Yes, artist goes in the art- category because the word is spelled with with art-. With your partner, continue to sort the rest of the words.
audio.notes: <visual: show words mark, part , bark, start, shark, artist, chart, dark, smart, park> <visual: show word artist> <visual: show the sorting cards art and ark in a pocket chart>

audio.transcription: What did you notice about the words in each group?

/är/ words don't have a long or short vowel sound for a. The letter r affects the vowel sound, making it different. You may notice the art- and ark- word spellings in many words. As we read, let's look for words with art- and ark-.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about political vocabulary. First, look at these two pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. voter <pause>, screen <pause>, ballot <pause>, box. Look at the voter in the picture. What is this person doing?
audio.notes: <visual: show vocabulary card>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about political vocabulary. The word is obstruct. Obstruct means to block or get in the way.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, obstruct>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, prolonged>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Dark Horse or Lame Duck?”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words obstruct and prolonged>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about political vocabulary? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 5 in your Unit 8 Student Book. The title of this text is "Taxes Help Everyone.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Taxes Help Everyone. You will read about taxes and what taxes pay for.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: employ. Employ is to give a job to someone. Schools employ many teachers and other staff, or workers. Which places employ nurses and doctors?
audio.notes: <visual: show student book and word, employ>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: show story>

audio.transcription: Find the first example of something that taxes pay for.
audio.notes: <visual: show story>

audio.transcription: What are some things that state governments tax? Find the sentences that answer this question.
The government employs many people. How do government workers benefit from taxes?
Do you think it is fair for citizens to pay taxes? What would happen if citizens did not pay taxes?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.

Write to Deepen Comprehension: Draw four boxes on a sheet of paper. <pause> Write an important fact about taxes in each box. Use these facts to write a one or two sentence summary of the text. <pause> Share your ideas with a partner before you write.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

toc.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Substitute Medial Vowel Sounds

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 8, Lesson 6. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 8.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 5 in your Unit 8 Student Book. Whisper read the text “Taxes Help Everyone” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 5 spread>

slides.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Substitute Medial Vowel Sounds

audio.transcription: Listen as I say a word: born
audio.notes: <visual: show Phonemic Awareness image>

audio.transcription: Say the word born, but change the middle sound. Change /ôr/ to /är/ What's the new word? <pause> barn
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
This is the sound-spelling card for the r-controlled vowel /är/. The "a-r" spelling stands for the /är/ sounds. What sounds does the "a-r" spelling make in the word "barn?" <pause> "/är/."
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for r-Controlled Vowel /är/>

audio.transcription: Write the spelling several times. Say the /är/ sounds each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Say the sound for each letter or spelling as your teacher points to it. Blend the sounds to read the word. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Let's review some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: move, never, once, round, small, their, too, walk, where, year.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word move. Say the word with me: "move"
Spell the word with me: m-o-v-e. The word "move" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it. Then, use the word in a sentence.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: never, once, round, small, their, too, walk, where, year.

Build Words Booster: Let's do some more word building. Listen carefully as your teacher tells you which word to make with your letter cards. Your teacher will check your work. Think about each sound in the word you are making. Use letter cards to spell the word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the letter cards to build the words>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 6 in your Unit 8 Student Book. Today we are going to read some cumulative sentences. These sentences contain words with ar spellings and other phonics skills we have learned. Let’s whisper read one sentence at a time. When you are done, we will chorally read them together.
audio.notes: <visual: Show Cumulative Sentences, pages 18-19>

audio.transcription: Circle all the words with ar spellings. <pause> Turn to a partner and read the words. Your teacher will listen in.
Write a sentence using the word shark. <pause> When you are finished, read your sentence to a partner.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word, shark>

audio.transcription: Write a sentence using each of these word pairs: hard/farm, artist/card.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word pairs hard/farm, artist/card>

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 8, Lesson 7. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 8.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 6 in your Unit 8 Student Book. Whisper read the cumulative sentences. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 6 spread>

audio.transcription: Review Phonics Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show phonics cards 19–45>

audio.transcription: Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show High-Frequency Word Cards 61–80>

audio.transcription: Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
This is the sound-spelling card for the r-controlled vowel /är/. The "a-r" spelling stands for the /är/ sounds. What sounds does the "a-r" spelling make in the word "barn?" <pause> "/är/."
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for r-Controlled Vowel /är/>

audio.transcription: Write the spelling several times. Say the /är/ sounds each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Let's do some more work with this unit's high-frequency words. Read: Look at the high-frequency words. Read each word along with me. move, <pause> never, <pause> once, <pause> round, <pause> small, <pause> their, <pause> too, <pause> walk, <pause> where, <pause> year.
audio.notes: <visual: show "move, never, once, round, small, their, too, walk, where, year" as cards in pocket-chart pockets, add one blank pocket-row, show tray with only letters for the first word.> [intended for teacher to model the first word]

audio.transcription: Build: Now let's build a word together. Watch as your teacher spells the word.
Now use your letter cards to build all the words.
Write: Write each word. Then write a sentence using each word. For example, you can start a sentence with "A ______ is a round object." Read your sentences to a partner when you are done.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence frame "A [blank] is a round object." Then show "move, never, once, round, small, their, too, walk, where, year" as cards in pocket-chart pockets underneath sentence frame>

audio.transcription: Now your teacher is going to make a word with letter cards. <pause> What is the word? <pause> Spell it together. <pause> Watch as your teacher scrambles the letters. Fix the spelling.
audio.notes: <visual: empty pocket rows with tray with letter cards for 2nd word>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 7 in your Unit 8 Student Book. The title of this text is "What Are Taxes Used For?" Point to the word as you read the title with me: What Are Taxes Used For? This shows what taxes are used for by displaying, or showing, a pie chart. The pie chart shows how much of Greenfield’s tax money goes to each service. The pie chart has colors and percentages. The percent is on each wedge. Each wedge identifies a service to show what the taxes pay for.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: What do you notice or wonder about when viewing the pie chart?
Draw and label a pie chart that identifies the favorite colors of the students in your class.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

toc.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
toc.title: Blending Focus

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 8, Lesson 8. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 8.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 7 in your Unit 8 Student Book. Whisper read the text “What Are Taxes Used For?” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 7 spread>

audio.transcription: Let's review inflectional endings. Inflectional endings change the tense of a verb, or action word. The "ed" ending shows that the action happened in the past. The "ing" ending shows that the action is happening now.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word star and the phonics/syllable cards "ed" and "ing">

audio.transcription: Some base words require spelling changes before adding the ending, such as doubling the final consonant or dropping the final "e."
Listen as I read the following word: "star." Before adding inflectional ending "ed" to "star," double the final consonant "r."
audio.notes: <visual: show the following: star star+r+ed starred (show "ed" in red font) >

audio.transcription: Now add the inflectional ending "ed" to the end of the word "star." What is the new word?
starred. <pause> Starred has two r's. "Starred" is a past-tense verb meaning that it already happened.
Before adding inflectional ending "ing" to the word "star," double the final consonant "r."
audio.notes: <show the following: star star+r+ing starring (show "ing" in red font) >

audio.transcription: Now add the inflectional ending "ing" to the end of the word "star." What is the new word?
starring. <pause> Starring has two r's. "Starring" is an action that's happening in the present, such as in the sentence: Raya is starring in the school play.
Practice adding inflectional endings "ed" and "ing" to the following words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the words fry, grab, and smile twice, once across from the phonics/syllable card ed and once across from the phonics/syllable card ing>

audio.transcription: This is the sound-spelling card for the r-controlled vowel /är/. The "a-r" spelling stands for the /är/ sounds. What sounds does the "a-r" spelling make in the word "barn?" <pause> "/är/."
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for r-Controlled Vowel /är/>

audio.transcription: Write the spelling several times. Say the /är/ sounds each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Let's find and circle all the words with art.
Now, let's put a box around all the words with -ed or -ing.

slides.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
slides.title: Blending Focus

audio.transcription: Blending Focus: Use your letter cards to build each word I say. Let's start by doing one together. Make the word cap. <pause> Change the letter p to r. What word did you make? Car
audio.notes: <visual: show the letter cards to build the words>

audio.transcription: Listen carefully as your teacher tells you the letter or letters to change to make the next word with your letter cards.

Let's build this set of words again. This time your teacher will not tell you which letters to change. Let's try one together: Make the word cap<pause>. Now change cap to car. Which sound is different? Which letter will be different?

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about the Statue of Liberty. First, look at these five pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. Statue of Liberty <pause>, crown <pause>, torch <pause>, tablet <pause>, pedestal. Look at the Statue of Liberty in the picture. What is the statue holding?
audio.notes: <visual: show vocabulary card>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about the Statue of Liberty. The word is occasion. An occasion is a special event, such as a wedding or a birthday party.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, occasion>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, symbol>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “The Story of Lady Liberty.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words occasion and symbol>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about the Statue of Liberty? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 8 in your Unit 8 Student Book. The title of this story is "A Special Lady.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: A Special Lady. You will read a story about a class trip to the Statue of Liberty.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this story: symbol. A symbol is something that represents, or stands for, an idea. A dove is a symbol of peace. What are some symbols that represent the United States?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, symbol>

audio.transcription: Read the story. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: show story>

audio.transcription: Find the name of the teacher leading the class trip.
audio.notes: <visual: show story>

audio.transcription: Who is the “special lady” Mr. Clark wants his students to meet? Find the sentences that answer the question.
What is the statue a symbol of? Can it be a symbol of more than one idea? Explain.
How do you think the students felt about Mr. Clark’s surprise? What makes you think so?
You can reread this story during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.

Write to Deepen Comprehension: Draw a picture to remember the important details in the story. <pause> Label the details, such as bus, Battery Park, Mr. Clark, Statue of Liberty, and New York Harbor. <pause> Use your drawing to retell the story to a partner. Then, write your retelling.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

toc.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 8, Lesson 9. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 8.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 8 in your Unit 8 Student Book. Whisper read the story “A Special Lady.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 8 spread>

audio.transcription: Review Phonics Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show phonics cards 19–45>

audio.transcription: Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show High-Frequency Word Cards 61–80>

audio.transcription: Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Finally, find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
This is the sound-spelling card for the r-controlled vowel /är/. The "a-r" spelling stands for the /är/ sounds. What sounds does the "a-r" spelling make in the word "barn?" <pause> "/är/."
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for r-Controlled Vowel /är/>

audio.transcription: Blend Words: Let's blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Say the word nice and loud.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Select two words from the list. Write a sentence for each word.

slides.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Listen to each word your teacher says. Write the word. If you need help, tap the sounds or use your sound boxes and counters to break up the word sound by sound. Then think about the letter that stands for each sound.
audio.notes: <visual: show phonemic awareness image>

audio.transcription: Let's start with these two words. Write the word spark.
Now write the word harvest.
Finally, write this sentence: Where is the small starfish with five arms?

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about ocean cleanup. First, look at these two pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. ocean <pause>, plastic waste <pause>, plastic bag <pause>, turtle. Look at the ocean in the picture. What is in the water?
audio.notes: <visual: show vocabulary card>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about ocean cleanup. The word is convert. When you convert something, you change it into something else.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, convert>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and word, banned>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Working Together on Ocean Cleanup.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words convert and banned>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about ocean cleanup? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 8 Student Book. The title of this text is "Community Workers.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Community Workers. This is a nonfiction text about different community jobs.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: essential. Essential is something that is needed. Pencils and paper are essential for writers. Which tools are essential to builders of houses? Chefs, who cook food? Artists?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, essential>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: show story>

audio.transcription: Find three things that mail carriers bring to people.
audio.notes: <visual: show story>

audio.transcription: Why are firefighters important community workers? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Why are teachers, bus drivers, mail carriers, police officers, and firefighters essential to our community? Explain.
Which job from this text would you like to have? Why?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Write about one other job that is important to the community. <pause> Share your ideas with a partner before you write.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

toc.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Blend and Segment Multisyllabic Words by Syllable

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 8, Lesson 10. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 8.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 8 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Community Workers.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 9 spread>

slides.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Blend and Segment Multisyllabic Words by Syllable

audio.transcription: Listen as I say the following syllables: car-toon
audio.notes: <visual: show phonemic awareness Image>

audio.transcription: Repeat the syllables and blend them to make a word. car-toon, cartoon.
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following syllables. Blend the syllables to make a word.
Now we will segment words into syllables. Listen as I say the following word: depart
Repeat the word and segment it into the syllables you hear. Depart, de-part.
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words. Segment each word into the syllables you hear.

Let's review inflectional endings "ed" and "ing." Inflectional endings are suffixes. A suffix is a word part that may be added to the end of a word. It can change the word’s meaning and part of speech.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "ed" and "ing">

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "carve." Add the inflectional ending "ed" to the end of "carve." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "carve" and the phonics/syllable cards for "ed" and "ing">

audio.transcription: "carved." <pause> "Carved" is the past-tense form of the verb "carve." The inflectional ending "ed" changes the tense of a verb, or action word. An example of carved in a sentence would be: He carved a slice of the turkey.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "carve" and the phonics/syllable cards for "ed", under them, show the word "carved">

audio.transcription: Now add the inflectional ending "ing" to the end of the word "carve." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "carve" and the phonics/syllable card "ing" across from it>

audio.transcription: "carving." <pause> The inflectional ending "ing" often shows that an action is happening now, so "carving" means that the action, "carve," is happening now as in the sentence: She was carving the turkey for dinner.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "carve" and the phonics/syllable card "ing" across from it, under them, show the word "carving">

audio.transcription: Practice adding the inflectional endings "ed" or "ing" to the following words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "ed" and "ing" and the following words: "farm," "charge," "march," "dry">

audio.transcription: Let's make a word ladder. I will give you a clue for each word to write on the word ladder.
audio.notes: <visual: empty word ladder with 6 rungs>

audio.transcription: This word names a place where horses live.
Change one letter in barn to name the sound a dog makes.
Change one letter in bark to describe what you do when you drive a car into a spot.
Add two letters to park to show that the action happened in the past.
Change one letter in parked to form a word that means “drew.”
Change one letter in marked to name a place to shop.
Let's do some more work with this unit's high-frequency words. Look at the high-frequency words.
audio.notes: <visual: move, never, once, round, small, their, too, walk, where, year>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher reads a high-frequency word from the list. Point to the word. Read the word. Spell the the word aloud.

Now build each high-frequency word using letter cards. Then work with a partner. Take turns scrambling the letters in the words. Rebuild each word. Watch as your teacher models scrambling and rebuilding the word "once."
audio.notes: <visual: pocket chart with 3rd word spelled out with letter cards: once>

audio.transcription: Now your teacher will ask you to read and write some words to check on your progress. Congratulations on all your hard work in Unit 8!
audio.notes: <visual: show Cumulative Assessment page 30>
